reviews.review_msg: Very harsh and ridiculous grading. Looks for exact words in the assignment and very unclear rubric. Almost impossible to get anything more than a B+.

The grading is ridicules. No logical or clear criteria on the grading and you are expected to read his mind. The course is not difficult but the highest grade on the assignments were around 65% because no one could tell what he wanted! You won't fail but this is not a GPA booster. The idea behind the course is interesting but the content is useless

Useless course! The grading is ridicules because there is no logical or clear criteria on the grading and you are expected to read his mind. The highest grade on the assignments were around 65% because no one could tell what he wanted! You won't fail but this is not a GPA booster. The idea behind the course is interesting but the content is useless

Is it easy to pass? Yes. Is it easy to get an A? No. The content only touches on broad business aspects that has little to do with comp sci. Ridinger is also incompetent at teaching as he just reads off the slides, and expects a lot from us but gives very little help. We need to read his mind or ask tons of questions to figure out the assignments.
what's wrong with this guy?!
whats wrong with this guy?!
Prob easiest course ever. You wont learn more things here, but just a gpa booster with 400 level credit
Easy course, lectures were boring because of the material.
Dan Ridinger is probably one of the professors at Simon Fraser University. Bro knows how to screw over his students by making the final assignment worth 50%. HAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHHHAHAHA.
he worked for an accounting company so he knows his stuff

Vague rubric for assignments. Unclear on what they take points away on. Refuses to give partial points. Unnecessarily made the entire final assignment (worth 50% of our grade) hard and the average for that was less than 50%. Very poor professor.

Learned absolutely nothing. This is NOT a GPA booster if you think so. Don't think that this course is "easy". The TAs don't give clear explanations for the markings. There is no rubric for the group assignments. The prof won't explain clearly why they marked a question that way. You must have the ability to read his mind to do well in this course.

While this could possibly be a good course, you learn absolutely nothing from this class. Every slide is a list of adjectives. Dan acts like there is only one correct way to make a diagram, and this is the only thing you "do" besides work with a broken system which was relevant for his Hanes project in the 90s. Take if you like drawing.

GPA booster is a lie. Don't fall into the pit that this course looked "easy". You don't know how you either got good marks or bad marks because you won't get understandable answers from the prof. Just pray to hope if you or your group mates could read his mind.

Avoid him. Lectures have no use on your study and assignments. You can't find a way to improve your grade when you are behind  but you also have no idea how got a good grade. If you are confused with assignments, you don't get clear answers from him or TA. You just use your intuition to do it. Lectures are light, but it's not GPA booster.

Dan is arguably one of the worst profs at SFU. His assignments are unclear and have no description or rubric, and when you ask questions he tells you to "read between the lines" which is impossible with his scrambled brain so you just lose marks. Lectures are boring so he makes attendance mandatory and curved down marks by >10% per student. AVOID!!
Unclear grading schemes, boring lectures, cryptic emails. Teaches you very well about incompetency as he is a first class example in it.

Marking criteria one of the poorest I have come across in any courses I've encountered so far. It is a writing course, but the corrections and comments are riddled with errors themselves. The rubric for grading had been consistently unclear throughout the course.

Awful lectures that have 0 relation to assignments. The worst part of this class was that he is deliberately uses confusing and vague wording for assignments, leaving you to literally guess what you have to do in order to satisfy his requirements that he pulls out of his ass. Then he docks you marks for not reading his mind. Unbelievably terrible.

Class has a pretty small workload, and that's about the only positive. No criteria for anything and Dan doesn't give clear answers so it's up to you to decipher what you need. He will dock marks for things he said you didn't need for seemingly no reason, and grades are mostly assigned at random because TAs don't know what's going on either. Avoid.

No clue what any of the assignments want you to do and if you ask questions his answers are more cryptic than the original description. 

The only thing I learned 4 months and hundreds of dollars later is that technical writing is a required course to graduate. thanks

DON'T take this class with Dan. His assignments are unclear and he doesn't give you a guideline to refer to. His answers to any questions about the course and assignments are vague and he refuses to further elaborate them. His lectures are long and monotonous and every single student that I've talked to has admitted that they are bored of him.
Assignments are confusing and ambiguous and trying to decode his answers to questions are just as difficult

This class is very good for a UD credit, and terrible for your CGPA. Dan makes sure everybody passes but keeps the average low. Assignments are all in groups and have the vaguest instructions, chasing the TA to clarify is the norm. Actual course content is useless at best, misleading at worst. Teaches from his own experience and is very subjective.

It's 2,3 days before the deadline and everyone is still very confused about what to do for the assignment. The links to the resources he uploaded that are the last hope to find out how to do the assignment are suddenly broken this close to the deadline and he responds  once a day

This class is a waste of time. The lectures have a bunch of vague, irrelevant content that you never use. He rambles on for 3 hours even though he could have delivered the content in 30 minutes. The group assignments are marked easily, but the final exam is marked super hard. Going to lectures didn't help at all for the final. Avoid him!

Don't take this class if you want to learn something. It is pretty light on content. The prof kind of rambles in lecture and the notes aren't great. He also gives lazy prompts for the assignments. They don't have enough description, and he tends to respond to questions with brief, unhelpful answers. Don't take this unless you need an easy class.

Honestly not a bad class. Show up - get 10%. Assignments are very vague, but this allows for freedom in answers (avg on assignments is high). This is nice except the TA mark assignments, and he is strict marking the final. Unless you get his answer then minimal marks. I think his experiences are beneficial, but he get sidetracked easily.

Useless lectures because assignment solutions were entirely different from in-class examples (ie Entity Relationship Diagram). Wouldn't tell me how he came up with his solutions. I took this course out of interest and was disappointed. However, it's hard to fail and easy to get an okay-ish grade.

If you want to learn something avoid Dan. His lectures are just a vessel for stroking his ego he makes sure you know how great he is and how his opinion is fact he is a very arrogant man, attendance is marked btw. Assignments are extremely vague but TA's mark pretty leniently. Final assignment is marked by him highest mark was 76% very hard marker.

He spends most lectures brushing his ego about all his past projects and thinks he knows how to avoid any software related problem in history. He talks about clarity and avoiding vagueness in requirements engineering, and then gives the most vague assignments and the correct solutions often involve contradicting constraints he's placed.

CMPT 475 is used for students who wants to graduate but do not have enough GPA. There are not so many students who want to take this class unless it is absolutely necessary. Courses like CMPT 475 or 376W are useless class and are normally not taught by by faculty members. It the co-op department did not screw my schedule. I would not take this.
Professor provided wrong solution to the assignments and refused to admit he is wrong. I have no idea why this trash exists in SFU.
Not knowledgeable, impractical assignment, even wrong software required for group work...
Very good professor. Loved every word he said. Take his class at all cost

All the assignments are marked very easily by a TA, giving you this idea that you understand the concepts well enough. The prof marks the final (which is an in-class assignment that simply re-hashes all the assignments in the class) completely differently. As his marking is not fair and all assignments are vague, I would avoid this class.
Vague assignments, stay away.
Your experience for the course depends upon your group. My group was horrible so I resent this course.

The truth about this course is that the assignments are meant to simulate what people would encounter when doing paid work.  Those that are going to employ you do not know what they want and are relying on you to give them the best recommendation based on your experience.  Understand the assignments and you'll do well on the final!
Easy course, take it for credit, no need to attend class, good prof
He is definitely the best professor I have ever met in my university life. 100% recommendation.
Incredibly vague assignments.

He is very helpful. He will help you in office hours (you probably will have to go). The lectures? Don't bother. Very dull. He spends maybe 40% of the class time talking about himself, honestly. Final was memorization from slides and assignment q's. This is a no programming course. He is VERY vague and unclear with his criteria. I emphasize VERY!

lots of experience, teaches practical hands on stuff that can nicely apply to real world work force, Assignment directions are abstract so make sure you ask questions (gets you ready for the real world... hardest part is knowing what questions to ask), no tricky exams

Assign aren't necessarily hard in terms of workload but because of extremely vague details and marking criteria, marks on avg are pretty low.  Assign consist of just making tasks in Feng Office which really only takes less than an hour of actual time.  TA doesn't read writing, don't bother.  Just make lots of tasks.  Final is vague.

Has real world experience and knows his material well.  Don't expect real world projects to be so giving.  The assignment details were somewhat unclear but he is willing to clarify if you seek information by asking questions.

grammar mistakes in his lecture course materials. ambiguous requirements for quizzes and exams. TA not helpful at all. group assignment class average very high. don't need textbook. open book final, marks are low. he doesn't reply emails. don't remember what i learned in class other than drawing diagrams

Very slow in replying emails and posting homework. He says he will post homework soon, but soon = 1 week later, which gives us less time to work on it and less chances of office hours. His notes he gives us are unreadable because they are extremely small and blurry. His ppt slides are very vague, I can learn more from a McDonald's menu. Good grief.

Probably the most useless professor I've ever had.  I'm not really sure how he's gotten any positive comments at all.  His assignments are fraught with spelling and grammar errors.  His tests are graded on whether you can guess the exact wording of a phrase he has in mind.  He doesn't teach the material, instead just rambles.  Overall, an F-.

First time he teaches this course.  Not bad for the first time, but there's room for improvement.  The largest problem is that his assignments are very terse and it's hard to figure out what exactly needs to be done.

Nice lecture, and is not a terribly boring speaker.  Grading is huge minus though.  The course material is very easy, but freaky marking means you get a mediocre grade no matter how hard you try.  Assignment directions are very vague and unhelpful.  Exam grading is rigid and oftimes illogical.

Lectures are very boring -- the course content is extremely easy, basically an extension of 275 without programming, however, the grading is scaled unfavorable to make the course seem harder than it is, it was a no brainer but somehow ended up with B- ???

It's "real world experience in a course" at it's best. High emphasis on design modeling, with most of it already being familiar at this level of education. He's clear and knows what he is talking about. 1st midterm based solely on notes and 2nd and final on models. Funny guy at times.

Prof has lots of real-world experience and teaches some practical things. You could get through the course without the textbook, save yourself some money. 1st midterm touched on it but was mostly from the notes. 2nd midterm and final you don't need the textbook.  Therefore, attending lecture is very important to learn how to make the diagrams.
it's not a hard course, but lecture is boring.

Great prof. who definitely knows his stuff. Notes are clear and detail enough that he can write a textbook based on it. Quizes, no midterms, are straightforward and easy to do (if you know your stuff). Projects are all case studies, and mostly on models/diagrams. Brings alot of experience and is a funny guy at times.
Good Prof, Knows his stuff very well. Could make classes a little bit more fun, but not bad overall.
